Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** 
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [4.13.0] 
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? 

### Description

I'm compiling bulma with my own scss using the following dependency and scripts:
```
"devDependencies": {
    "autoprefixer": "^9.7.3",
    "clean-css-cli": "^4.3.0",
    "node-sass": "^4.13.0",
    "postcss-cli": "^6.1.3",
    "postcss-focus-within": "^3.0.0",
    "rimraf": "^3.0.0"
  },
  "browserslist": [
    "last 2 versions"
  ],
  "scripts": {
    "build": "npm run build-clean && npm run build-scss && npm run build-autoprefix && npm run build-cleancss",
    "build-autoprefix": "postcss --use autoprefixer --map false --output style.css style.css",
    "build-cleancss": "cleancss -o style.min.css style.css",
    "build-clean": "rimraf css",
    "build-scss": "node-sass ./scss/style.scss style.css --output-style expanded --source-map true",
    "deploy": "npm run build",
    "start": "npm run build-scss -- --watch"
  },
```

when I try and compile it using npm run deploy it gives me the following error:
```
{
  "status": 1,
  "file": "/var/docker-stack/wordpress/themes/blackout_v1/scss/bulma/sass/base/generic.sass",
  "line": 5,
  "column": 15,
  "message": "Undefined variable: \"$family-primary\".",
  "formatted": "Error: Undefined variable: \"$family-primary\".\n        on line 5 of scss/bulma/sass/base/generic.sass\n        from line 4 of scss/bulma/sass/base/_all.sass\n        from line 5 of scss/style.scss\n>> $body-family: $family-primary !default;\n\n   --------------^\n"
}
```

### Steps to Reproduce

added the scss as explained the documentation

style.scss
```
@charset "utf-8";

@import "variables";

@import "bulma/sass/base/_all";

@import "_partials/_header";
@import "_partials/_front-page";
@import "_partials/_footer"
```
and I got the aforementioned error: 
```
{
  "status": 1,
  "file": "/var/docker-stack/wordpress/themes/blackout_v1/scss/bulma/sass/base/generic.sass",
  "line": 5,
  "column": 15,
  "message": "Undefined variable: \"$family-primary\".",
  "formatted": "Error: Undefined variable: \"$family-primary\".\n        on line 5 of scss/bulma/sass/base/generic.sass\n        from line 4 of scss/bulma/sass/base/_all.sass\n        from line 5 of scss/style.scss\n>> $body-family: $family-primary !default;\n\n   --------------^\n"
}
```

### Expected behavior

Compile the SCSS without error and allow me to override variables.

### Actual behavior

It printed the error:

```
{
  "status": 1,
  "file": "/var/docker-stack/wordpress/themes/blackout_v1/scss/bulma/sass/base/generic.sass",
  "line": 5,
  "column": 15,
  "message": "Undefined variable: \"$family-primary\".",
  "formatted": "Error: Undefined variable: \"$family-primary\".\n        on line 5 of scss/bulma/sass/base/generic.sass\n        from line 4 of scss/bulma/sass/base/_all.sass\n        from line 5 of scss/style.scss\n>> $body-family: $family-primary !default;\n\n   --------------^\n"
}

```

Issues.Title: [Feature/Question] How to use CSS variables?
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about Bulma.

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma 0.7.5.
My **browser** is: Chrome

### Description

I do not know if it's a Feature request or a Question, but I would like to be able to override the Sass variables by CSS variables. The final goal is to offer the end user to be able to customize the theme of the site by updating some CSS variables using Javacript.
Right now, I'm pretty sure it's not possible, but I am ok do discuss the subject, offer solutions and even implement them.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set CSS variables, for instance:
`
:root {
    --primary: red;
  }
`
2. Using SCSS, override Bulma variables. For instance:
`$primary:var(--primary, blue) !default;`
`
3. Import Bulma SASS files:
`@import "~bulma/sass/utilities/_all";`

### Expected behavior

Be able to compile and update CSS variables using Javascript syntax:
`document.documentElement.style
    .setProperty('--primary', 'pink');`

### Actual behavior

Compile and see a Sass-loader error.

Issues.Title: Fixes #2741: Update form inputs derived variables
Issues.Body:
Use `$grey-darker` and `$grey` as default instead of `$text-strong` and `$text-light` which may contain the "inherit" value (fixes issue #2741)

<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is an **improvement / bugfix**.
<!-- New feature? Update the CHANGELOG.md too, and eventually the Docs. -->
<!-- Improvement? Explain how and why. -->
<!-- Bugfix? Reference that issue as well. -->

I ran into a compiling error with Bulma 0.8.0 when trying to use `inherit` value for the `$text-strong` variable. I found out this is due to breaking changes in commit 0f988eadd9cbca055966e4418a704b85e19999ff in which a lot of default colors have been modified. This particular line was throwing the error when using `inherit` value for `$text-strong`:

```
$input-placeholder-color: rgba($text-strong, 0.3) !default
``` 

I think we may often use this particular value for the `$text-strong` and `$text-light` variables because there are a lot of cases where a `<strong>` tag in a text should just inherit its parent color. 
Also I think it doesn't really make sense to use the strong text color as default in any other derived variable.

### Proposed solution

<!-- Which specific problem does this PR solve and how?  -->
<!-- If it fixes a particular Issue, add "Fixes #ISSUE_NUMBER" in your title -->
In this PR I just put back the old default values, replacing `$text-strong` by `$grey-darker` and `$text-light` by `$grey`. By the way this is what [the docs](https://bulma.io/documentation/form/input/#variables) actually says.

### Tradeoffs

<!-- What are the drawbacks of this solution? Are there alternative ones? -->
<!-- Think of performance, build time, usability, complexity, coupling…) -->
There are still other derived variables which use the `$text-strong` and `$text-light` ones as default. All of these changes have been made in commit 0f988eadd9cbca055966e4418a704b85e19999ff.  
Maybe it could be a better idea to roll back the whole commit but I'm not really sure about that.

### Testing Done

<!-- BEFORE SUBMITTING YOUR PR, MAKE SURE TO FOLLOW THESE STEPS: -->
<!-- 1. Pull the latest `master` branch -->
<!-- 2. Make sure your Sass code is compliant with the [Bulma Sass styleguide](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#bulma-sass-styleguide) -->
<!-- 3. Make sure your PR only affects `.sass` or documentation files -->
<!-- 4. [Try your changes](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#try-your-changes). -->

<!-- How have you confirmed this feature works? -->
<!-- Please explain more than "Yes". -->

I did test this PR in my project. Using `$text-strong: inherit` does not throw a compiling error anymore.

### Changelog updated?

No.

<!-- Thanks! -->

Issues.Title: Can't use inherit value anymore since 0.8.0
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.8.0]
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [0.8.0]
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->
Before version 0.8.0, we were able to use `inherit` values for colors. I used to override `$text-strong` variable so it takes an inherited color instead of a hardcoded one.  

```
$text-strong: inherit
```

Since 0.8.0, using inherit value for this particular variable throws the following error when compiling with Sass:

```
ERROR in ./resources/sass/app.scss
Module build failed (from ./node_modules/css-loader/index.js):
ModuleBuildError: Module build failed (from ./node_modules/sass-loader/dist/cjs.js):

$input-placeholder-color: rgba($input-color, 0.3) !default
                         ^
      $color: inherit is not a color.
  ╷
6 │ $input-placeholder-color: rgba($input-color, 0.3) !default
  │                           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  ╵
  node_modules/bulma/sass/form/shared.sass 6:27  @import
  node_modules/bulma/sass/form/_all.sass 3:9     @import
  node_modules/bulma/bulma.sass 6:9              @import
  stdin 9:9                                      root stylesheet
```

I rolled back to Bulma 0.7.5 and Sass compiles without throwing any error.  

An issue has been posted about this more than two years ago. @wrabit suggested to use `inherit` as a workaround but this is not working anymore. https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/issues/821#issuecomment-539953034

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
1. First Step
2. Second Step
3. and so on...
-->
1. Override `$text-strong` variable with the value `inherit`
2. Compile with Sass

### Expected behavior

<!-- What you expected to happen -->
We should be able to use `inherit` values without Sass throwing an error.

### Actual behavior

<!-- What actually happened -->
Sass throws an error when compiling.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Can't use inherit value anymore since 0.8.0" (#2741)

Issues.Title: [Question] Is the documented limitations for Control correct or is it overly generalized?
Issues.Body:
This is about **the Docs**. This is a **question**. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** This is about the Bulma **Docs** I'm using Bulma **version** [0.7.4] My **browser** is: Google Chrome Version 78.0.3904.108 (Official Build) (64-bit) I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** ### Description The documentation for [form control ](https://bulma.io/documentation/form/general/#form-control)says: > The Bulma control is a versatile block container meant to enhance single form controls. Because it has the same height as the element that it wraps, it can only contain the following Bulma elements: > > * `input` > * `select` > * `button` > * `icon` However, in reading the blog post from 2017 where [control was split into field and control in v.04.0](https://bulma.io/2017/03/10/new-field-element/), the examples cover using a `span` inside a control and why I can't have a complex control of HTML elements inside a control element: ```html

This username is available

This username is available

``` ### Steps to Reproduce Not exactly steps to reproduce, but additional context: I'm asking specifically because I want to use Bulma with Telerik Kendo UI, and Kendo UI translates it's "`` element into something like the following for an empty dropdown list, and its top-level elements are span and input, which violates the rules in the Bulma documentation HOWEVER everything seems to "work ok" - I think this is because the span is actually the floating listbox and therefore not part of the actual layout rules applied by Bulma, but it's been about 3+ years since I last did Web apps: ```html

``` ### Expected behavior Clarify documentation that a control can contain the four elements, or any element that is not directly in the layout of the control element (e.g., floating above as in a pop-up control) ### Actual behavior It seems to be OK to have spans and other elements, as long as it's not directly in the element's "has layout" path. But, again, it's been 3+ years since I've built a Web app, so I may be overlooking something, especially with Flexbox, as this is my first Flexbox app.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Question] Is the documented limitations for Control correct or is it overly generalized?" (#2728)

Issues.Title: Part 3: What's with Jeremy Thomas closing important issues before we even get a chance to reply?
Issues.Body:
> It seems your ideas are not compatible with the very foundation of Bulma: CSS classes are independent from the underlying HTML. This separation method allows the semantics of the HTML to be freely chosen by the user.
>
> That's why people pick Bulma: they can simply add some base classes, a few modifiers, and their styling is done!
>
> You write the HTML you want. Bulma does the rest.

That's the point I'm trying to make -- that this is simply just idn't the case!

Bulma allows you to add a few cases, a few modifiers, and you're done -- that part is fine.

But, unfortunately, Bulma requires you to drastically alter your HTML, and even insert unnecessary tags where classes could be used instead. You talk about me not understanding semantic HTML, with all due respect I think it's the other way around.

I'm just asking you to make Bulma more consistent by sticking to your core principle of using clean, simple and self-explanatory classes without interfering with ones HTML up to the point where you have to use old style tags to get what you want, and in addition put tags inside tags inside tags inside tags like some sort of Russian doll.

Having said that, I wish you good luck as well, and may all of Bootstrap's users become your users one day. Cheers!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Part 3: What's with Jeremy Thomas closing important issues before we even get a chance to reply?" (#2725)

Curious though, why certainly didn't let me respond to any of your points. Not letting people properly present their case, especially when they're trying to help Bulma improve, is both extremely rude and arrogant.

You seem to think that you are right and everyone else is wrong. Earlier you claimed that this place here on GitHub was the place for the community to discuss matters surrounding Bulma. But that's just a load of BS judging by the way you're acting right now.
